Award.AwardTitle: CC* Network Design: Network Infrastructure for Improved Student Engagement in Science Discovery and Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
DePauw University has a strong history of undergraduate participation in science research and education through its rich science curriculum, experiential programs in science and technology, high-impact teaching practices, and nationally recognized teaching and mentoring. DePauw graduates in science, technology, and mathematics are well-prepared to successfully enter graduate school and careers, many receiving prestigious postgraduate scholarships or fellowships.

This project improves DePauw's cyberinfrastructure and internet connectivity in three areas to reduce limitations that hinder effective data exchange and use of remote applications in the process of scientific discovery and education, by increasing the campus connection to national research networks through Indiana's regional network provider, ILight, from 1Gpbs to 10Gbps; creating internet redundancy via a secondary fiber optic link to I-Light; and implementing a re-architected network border prioritizing science data flows with high performance data transfer and PerfSonar nodes.

These improvements address immediate research needs for DePauw projects in computer science, biology, and chemistry that are improving understanding of tools for developing interactive documents that blend text and data-driven arguments, adding to general understanding of heart regeneration with the potential to influence treatments for heart-attacks, helping the scientific community better understand how cutting-edge DNA sequencing technology can help patients with rare genetic diseases, and supporting women computer science students to persist in computational fields by decreasing feelings of isolation through online interaction with mentors and role models. Further, these improve access to national research networks and resources that enables DePauw to expose a greater number of undergraduate students to participation in innovative science research and discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Campus Cyberinfrastructure (CC*) Network Design and Implementation for Small Institutions project improved access to national research networks and resources that will enable DePauw University science faculty and undergraduate students to more effectively conduct innovative science research and engage in scholarly collaborations across multiple scientific disciplines. This was achieved by improving the campus cyberinfrastructure (CI) and connectivity to Internet2 and internet-based science research resources, removing limitations hindering effective data exchange and using remote applications in the process of scientific discovery and education.

The project accomplished this as follows: It increased the campus connection to national research networks via Indiana's regional network provider, I-Light, to 10Gbps. It built critical campus network redundancy by adding a secondary 10Gbps fiber optic link to Internet2 that connects via I-Light to Wabash College and bridges a new loop in the I-Light regional network to improve network georedundancy for other higher education institutions in Indiana. It implemented a science DMZ with high performance data transfer node with all-flash storage and a PerfSONAR host.

This two-year project focused on research and development of the CI technical design during year one, followed by implementation during year two. Once the CI improvements were in place, the project co-PIs could begin work as described in four proposed science use cases, each demonstrating intellectual merit resulting from opportunities created by the CI improvements, including: A computer science project would improve understanding of tools that enable authors to develop interactive documents that blend text and data-driven arguments. A biology project would add to general understanding of heart regeneration, with the long-term potential to influence treatments for heart-attacks. A chemistry project would help the scientific research community better understand how cutting-edge DNA sequencing technology can help patients with rare genetic diseases. Finally, a project would support women computer science students to persist in computational fields by decreasing feelings of isolation through interaction with mentors and role models using video conferences.

As planned, the CI improvements were completed at the end of the CC* grant period and three of the case projects had not yet begun work. However, the computer science project, "Reactive Documents," as well as an additional NSF International Research Experiences for Students (NSF IRES) STEM project, were underway and will be impacted greatly with the improved CI infrastructure.

"Reactive Documents."
Co-PI Dr. Dave Berque, professor of Computer Science, worked with undergraduate researchers on a project related to reactive documents. Reactive documents [Victor, B. Explorable explanations. http://worrydream.com/ExplorableExplanations, 2011] are a cross between textual documents and quantitative information, which can include visualizations. The team designed and implemented a reactive document editor prototype that would allow end users to author a reactive document as easily as writing a text document or constructing a spreadsheet. Initial work focused on building functionality to support reactive documents backed by formulas. The system generates code that uses Victor's JavaScript library to support a reactive document without the user needing to see that code directly. In spring 2019 the team began to augment the base project with functionality that supports reactive documents backed by data sets; that work continues. DePauw's expanded CI environment expands the work conducted by these researchers by enabling exploration of larger data sets than would have been impossible prior to the CI improvements through this CC* project.

NSF IRES Project.
In summer 2019, co-PI Berque and Dr. Hiroko Chiba, DePauw professor of Asian Studies, were awarded an NSF IRES grant, "IRES Track One: Involving Undergraduates in Research on Design and Cross-Cultural Perceptions of Cuteness in Robotic Gadgets." The IRES grant will enable DePauw undergraduate researchers over three summers (2020, 2021 and 2022) to conduct research at the Japanese Shibaura Institute of Technology (SIT). These student researchers will collaborate with Dr. Berque, Dr. Chiba, and SIT students and faculty to design prototypes of robotic gadgets with varying levels and types of kawaii (Japanese cuteness) and conduct multi-site, cross-cultural experiments from a user-study suite that measures a user's emotional reaction to the gadgets using measurements obtained through self-reports and biosensors. The researchers will gather data from subjects in the United States and Japan to compare user reactions across culture and gender with the aim of understanding how to design devices that are accepted by diverse users. 

One challenge in running a cross-cultural, multi-site user study involving prototypes of robotic gadgets involves replicability. It is difficult to build several identical prototypes for use at different sites and to build several versions of each prototype that incorporate different kawaii properties. Therefore, the researchers will explore using stereoscopic 3D video to record each prototype and present it consistently to users at different sites. DePauw's expanded CI environment and high-speed data transfer capabilities will enable the researchers to efficiently transfer these large video files between DePauw and SIT.
